Author: SwellJoe
Content:
As a possible alternative view: I've made a living for the past 7 or 8 years from Virtualmin, despite the fact that we give away 99% of the code under a GPL license. The underlying core Webmin is free under a BSD license, and has millions of users, including countless commercial users who have distribute custom versions of Webmin for their management UI, none paying a dime to use it.

We have literally 100 users who don't pay us anything for every one who does pay us something. It's possible we'd make more money if we didn't make FOSS...but, it's also possible we would simply have two orders of magnitude fewer users (or maybe even zero users, it's a competitive market, and our competitors spend a lot more on marketing and sales than we have the resources for). I'd rather have a million users and a thousand paying for it than just a thousand users.

In short, I'm not telling you how to run your business. Just pointing out that there are other ways to think about, and deal with, "free loaders". They can potentially be your fans, your testing staff, your marketing team, and your eventual paying customers.

Author: beagle3
Content:
I don't think a simplified C as such exists. The dark corners are part of C's identity, and you can't even use the standard C library without being aware of them (buffer overflows, arrays vs. pointers, etc.); And if it did exist, it would be almost useless to the point that no example you would find anywhere would work on it.

Go back one step: Why would you want one? Pascal / FreePascal / Delphi Pascal might work for you (dark corners not an essential part of the language, pretty comparable to C, albeit more verbose). Or there's D, which is very similar to C, has much fewer dark corners if any, but "simplified" is not how I would describe it.
